Abstract: This review highlights recent advancements in the development of sustainable polymers derived from biological matter, emphasizing their potential to replace traditional petrochemical-based materials. The focus is on biopolymers and biocomposites, which are increasingly being utilized in various applications, including construction and packaging. Key areas of progress include the enhancement of mechanical properties, thermal stability, and biodegradability of these materials. The integration of renewable resources, such as lignocellulosic fibers and agricultural by-products, into cementitious materials is also discussed, showcasing their role in reducing environmental impact. The review concludes with an outlook on future research directions, emphasizing the need for scalable and economically viable processes to facilitate the widespread adoption of sustainable polymers.
